Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Development of a Stoichiometric, Direct-Injected, Soot-Free Engine for Heavy-Duty Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project will focus on the development of a new alternative to Diesel engines for use in heavy-duty applications such as on-road transportation, off-road farm equipment, and stationary power generation. Currently, Diesel engines are used in all of these applications because they are robust and powerful. Unfortunately, they also produce significant smog, soot, and greenhouse gases that are damaging to individuals and the environment. In contrast, the engines developed under this project will have cleaner exhaust while producing more power at increased efficiency, all while utilizing inexpensive alternative fuels. Since Diesel-fueled engines move 70% of the world's goods, and produce 30% of distributed power around the globe, these engines are inextricably linked to quality of life, and transformational improvements in their operation can have a large, broad, positive impact on society. This project's new engines will continue to provide essential services, but in a way that reduces operating costs (creating savings that can be passed on to consumers) and emissions (further saving consumers money, and improving air quality in heavily-trafficked regions). These engines will fulfill a critical market need for clean, powerful engine solutions, and can be integrated into existing American-made engine product lines, increasing manufacturing revenue, stimulating job creation, and ensuring that the United States will remain a global leader heavy-duty engine production.


This project will focus on enabling these clean, powerful engines by developing a novel, high-temperature combustion system that allows traditional engines to be adapted to burn alternative fuels in an efficient and soot-free manner. This requires integration of a unique combination of technologies, joined in a way that provides benefits far greater than those that can be achieved with the individual components in isolation. Removing any piece from this specific combination drastically reduces performance. Because each component plays a critical role, this project has high risk (as each subsystem must function properly), but its sophistication also presents a high barrier to similar efforts (since incorrect use of any component yields significantly worse results). This project will build on previous proof-of-concept data that verified the feasibility of this concept, and will focus on the development of key engine subsystems, seeking to mitigate risk enough that investment from the private sector is possible. At the end of the project, the subsystems will be integrated into a stationary power generator as a retrofit to an existing Diesel engine, adapting it for alternative fuel use. This would serve as a prototype platform for the technology?illustrating its increased efficiency and power, along with reduced emissions?and demonstrating the value of the technology to market incumbents, hopefully spurring a licensing arrangement for engine production.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF Phase I SBIR project worked towards developing a high-temperature combustion system that would allow high-efficiency Diesel-style combustion of low-carbon liquid fuels like ethanol and methanol. This system, known as the "ClearFlame Combustion System" (or "CFCS"), would create a new line of heavy-duty engines that can deliver the high power and efficiency demanded in commercial applications, while also lowering fuel costs and reducing environmental impact. In order to make this technology a reality, this project focused on 1) developing the required engine insulation, 2) exploring pathways to enable alcohol direct injection, and 3) optimizing design of the combustion chamber for stoichiometric operation with exhaust gas load control. ClearFlame was able to achieve promising results in all of these areas, which showed how:

  • 1) Engine insulation could be applied in a way that increases efficiency and promotes ignition of low-cetane fuels, all while prioritizing insulation robustness and realistic scaling and cost targets to accommodate commercialization. This result helps advance the state of thermal coating technology in a way that can be applied to a range of heavy-duty engines.
  • 2) Lubricity enhancers could be used in trace amounts to improve fuel properties, while injector modifications could be made to increase material compatibility. This demonstrates that low-lubricity fuels could be used in heavy-duty engine applications with minimal modification, maintaining the economic value proposition of the fuels.
  • 3) Piston designs could be modeled and fabricated to improve engine performance, better optimizing the CFCS for stoichiometric operation with exhaust gas load control. This shows how heavy-duty engine design can be re-optimized to make better use of fuel resources, once a system has been designed to achieve naturally low emissions.

These results show that ClearFlame has been able to add to the scientific understanding of how to better use alcohol fuels and thermal coatings in internal combustion engines, while also unlocking a pathway to reduce the carbon impact and hazardous emissions of Diesel-dominated sectors. A brief summary of the goals and results is provided here, with the most relevant conclusions summarized the accompanying Table.

Goal #1: Experimental and modeling tests of engine insulation

Testing of engine insulation requires that a fundamental trade-off in system design be addressed: more effective insulation (in terms of heat transfer reduction) generally leads to a reduction in coating durability. Fortunately, ClearFlame's insulation requirements are different than previous approaches, allowing the CFCS to achieve added benefits from engine insulation while simultaneously reducing the typically-concurrent drawbacks. ClearFlame focused on coatings with a relatively high density, improving coating durability. The resulting experiments validated an 18% reduction in heat transfer, an 18C decrease in the required intake heating, and a 5% increase in efficiency. Taken together, this achieved the Phase I goals of enabling fuel ignitability and reduced heat transfer losses without compromising durability, a result that can also be extended to other engine applications.

Goal #2: Development of an alcohol-tolerant fuel injection system

High-pressure direct-injection of alcohol fuels has different requirements than corresponding Diesel systems. ClearFlame was able to quantify the increase in injection mass needed to reach stoichiometric fuel loadings for alcohol fuels. Further, ClearFlame was able to demonstrate that trace amounts of lubricity improver could be used to dramatically increase fuel compatibility with existing injection systems, without requiring significant added cost or compromising performance and emissions. The negligible effect of lubricity additive on performance and emissions will make optimizing combustion with fewer injector modifications possible. This benefit has illuminated new pathways to using low-lubricity fuels in heavy-duty engines.

Goal #3: Designing new combustion chamber geometries and spray characteristics with CFD

Engine combustion chambers are highly-optimized for specific fuels. Since Diesel fuel produces significant emissions, piston designs are often chosen to mitigate soot and/or NOx formation. ClearFlame chose to adjust piston geometry and injection spray angle to re-optimize the combustion for alcohol fuels. A combination of engine experiments and CFD was used to improve key metrics of combustion performance, specifically increasing the rate and extent of fuel conversion, and reducing heat transfer. ClearFlame was able to use CFD modeling to find new designs that could decrease heat transfer by 4%, and also increase thermal efficiency by 2.4 percentage points (with a 67% decrease in soot emissions) due to improved combustion phasing and air utilization. ClearFlame is currently testing pistons and injectors designed based on the results of their Phase I work. These experimental and modeling results can be utilized in a range of alcohol engine configurations.
